verses.text: So also, if anything is true, it is assuredly from Truth that it is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:3
verses.text: What? When a chaste person dies, do you judge that Chastity dies also? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:4
verses.text: By no means.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:6
verses.text: Then, when anything perishes that is true, Truth perishes not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:8
verses.text: But how should anything true perish? For I see not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:9
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:10
verses.text: I marvel that you ask that question: do we not see thousands of things perish before our eyes? Unless perchance you think this tree, either to be a tree, but not a true one, or if so to be unable to perish.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:11
verses.text: For even if you believe not your senses, and are capable of answering, that you are wholly ignorant whether it is a tree; yet this, I believe, you will not deny, that it is a true tree, if it is a tree: for this judgment is not of the senses, but of the intelligence.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:12
verses.text: For if it is a false tree, it is not a tree; but if it is a tree, it cannot but be a true one.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:13
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:14
verses.text: This I allow.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:16
verses.text: Then as to the other proposition; do you not concede that a tree is of such a sort of things, as that it originates and perishes? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:17
verses.text: I cannot deny it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:19
verses.text: It is con  cluded therefore, that something which is true perishes.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:20
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:21
verses.text: I do not dispute it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:22
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:23
verses.text: What follows? Does it not seem to thee that when true things perish Truth does not perish, as Chastity dies not when a chaste person dies? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:24
verses.text: I now grant this too, and eagerly wait to see what thou art laboring to show.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:25
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:26
verses.text: Therefore attend.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:27
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 28:28
verses.text: I am all attention.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:3
verses.text: Does this proposition seem to you to be true: Whatever is, is compelled to be somewhere? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:4
verses.text: Nothing so entirely wins my consent.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:6
verses.text: And you confess that Truth is? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:7
verses.text: I confess it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:9
verses.text: Then we must needs inquire where it is; for it is not in a place, unless perchance you think there is something else in a place than a body, or think that Truth is a body.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:10
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:11
verses.text: I think neither of these things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:13
verses.text: Where then do you believe her to be? For she is not nowhere, whom we have granted to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:14
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:15
verses.text: If I knew where she was, perchance I should seek nothing more.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:16
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:17
verses.text: At least you are able to know where she is not? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:18
verses.text: If thou pass in review the places, perchance I shall be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:19
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:20
verses.text: It is not, assuredly, in mortal things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:21
verses.text: For whatever is, cannot abide in anything, if that does not abide in which it is: and that Truth abides, even though true things perish, has just been conceded.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:22
verses.text: Truth, therefore, is not in mortal things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:23
verses.text: But Truth is, and is not nowhere.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:24
verses.text: There are therefore things immortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:25
verses.text: And nothing is true in which Truth is not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:26
verses.text: It results therefore that nothing is true, except those things which are immortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:27
verses.text: And every false tree is not a tree, and false wood is not wood, and false silver is not silver, and everything whatever which is false, is not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:28
verses.text: Now everything which is not true, is false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:29
verses.text: Nothing therefore is rightly said to be, except things immortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:30
verses.text: Do you diligently consider this little argument, lest there should be in it any point which you think impossible to concede.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 29:31
verses.text: For if it is sound, we have almost accomplished our whole business, which in the other book will perchance appear more plainly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:3
verses.text: I thank thee much, and will diligently and cautiously review these things in my own mind, and moreover with thee, when we are in quiet, if no darkness interfere, and, which I vehemently dread, inspire in me delight in itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:4
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:5
verses.text: Steadfastly believe in God, and commit thyself wholly to Him as much as thou canst.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:6
verses.text: Be not willing to be as it were thine own and in thine own control; but profess thyself to be the bondman of that most clement and most profitable Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:7
verses.text: For so will He not desist from lifting thee to Himself, and will suffer nothing to occur to thee, except what shall profit thee, even though thou know it not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:8
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:9
verses.text: I hear, I believe, and as much as I can I yield compliance; and most intently do I offer a prayer for this very thing, that I may have the utmost power, unless perchance thou desirest something more of me.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:10
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book I 30:11
verses.text: It is well meanwhile, thou wilt do afterwards what He Himself, being now seen, shall require of thee.
